questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is responsible for UTI in a diabetic patient, and urine culture showing gram-positive, spectacle shape, non-motile, non-sporing, survives in the presence of 6.5% NaCl and exhibits resistance to 40% bile and shows a positive PYR test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Enterococcus species

The clinical presentation and the microbiological characteristics described in the question are indicative of an Enterococcus species infection. Enterococci are Gram-positive cocci that have a unique "spectacle" shape when observed under the microscope. They are non-motile and non-sporing. Additionally, Enterococcus species are known for their resistance to various environmental stressors, including 6.5% NaCl (survival in high salt conditions) and 40% bile (resistance to bile). The positive PYR test is another characteristic feature of Enterococcus species.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe watery diarrhea and abdominal cramps following recent travel to a rural area in a neighboring country. Lab results show leukocytosis and elevated creatinine levels. Stool culture reveals a Gram-negative, non-lactose fermenting bacillus. Which toxin, acting on the 60s ribosome to decrease protein synthesis, is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shiga toxin

The clinical presentation described in this scenario, including severe watery diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and leukocytosis, is highly suggestive of a Shiga toxin-producing bacteria infection. Shiga toxin is a potent toxin produced by certain strains of Gram-negative bacteria, most commonly Shigella dysenteriae and some serotypes of Escherichia coli. Shiga toxin acts on the 60s ribosome in the host cell, leading to inhibition of protein synthesis. This inhibition affects protein production within the host cells, particularly in endothelial cells of the gastrointestinal tract and kidneys, causing severe damage and leading to the characteristic symptoms observed in this patient.

questions.text: What is the most likely laboratory diagnosis for a 25-year-old male with diarrhea after consuming contaminated food, whose laboratory tests for bacterial identification show positive results for glucose, lactose, maltose, and sucrose fermentation, along with positive Indole and Methyl red but negative Voges proskauer and citrate utilization in IMViC test results?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Escherichia coli

The patient's symptoms of diarrhea and abdominal cramps, along with the given IMViC test results, suggest an infection caused by Escherichia coli (E. coli). E. coli is a gram-negative bacterium commonly associated with gastrointestinal infections. The IMViC test is a set of four biochemical tests used to differentiate between members of the Enterobacteriaceae family, including E. coli.

questions.text: A small tick, of the genus Ixodes, most commonly transmits B. burgdorferi. Which of the following diseases is also transmitted by a tick?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ehrlichiosis

Similar to Lyme disease, ehrlichiosis is also transmitted via a tick vector

questions.text: A 29-year-old bird collector presents to the local clinic with what he describes as flu-like symptoms. He doesn’t look ill, and has a slight fever, headache, and a dry hacking cough. He denies the production of sputum or hemoptysis. There are no crackles heard on auscultation, and a radiograph shows small streaks of infiltrate. It is determined that he has pneumonia. What is the most likely organism causing his disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Although all of the organisms listed above cause pneumonia, only two of them are atypical. Atypical pneumonia is characterized by a dry hacking cough, fever, and headache. These include C. psittaci and C. pneumoniae. The mention of birds should point you in the direction of C. psittaci, because they are the reservoir for the organism that is inhaled through dry feces. Typical pneumonias are characterized by hemoptysis of pus-laden sputum, and patients appear very sick.

questions.text: A hospitalized patient developed severe diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis within 5 days after antibiotic therapy was initiated. The severe diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis occurred as a result of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Clostridium difficile produces two toxins, Toxins A and B. Both toxins are present in stool samples. Toxin A is enterotoxic causing the severe diarrhea, whereas Toxin B is cytotoxic leading to the destruction of enterocytes resulting in pseudomembranous colitis.

questions.text: Testing of blood culture isolates from a hospitalized patient revealed grampositive cocci, β-lactamase positive, vancomycin-resistant, PYR-positive, and the presence of Lancefield group D antigen. Which of the following is the most likely isolate identification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

All bacteria listed are gram-positive cocci. Streptococcus pneumoniae does not have a Lancefield grouping, whereas S. agalactiae has a group B classification. Streptococcus bovis is PYR-negative. Thus, only E. faecalis fulfills all laboratory test results in the above question.

questions.text: Several children are hospitalized with bloody diarrhea and severe hematological abnormalities. A 4-year-old girl dies of kidney failure shortly after admittance. An epidemiological investigation establishes that all of the patients developed symptoms following consumption of hamburgers from the same fast-food restaurant chain. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible for the outbreak?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Escherichia coli 0157:H7 strains are classically associated with outbreaks of diarrhea after ingestion of undercooked hamburger at fastfood restaurants. Many cases of hemorrhagic colitis and its associated complications can be prevented by thoroughly cooking ground beef. The other organisms listed can cause GI disturbances; however, E. coli is the classic disturbing pathogen in this case. Shigella dysenteriae produces a heat-labile enterotoxin that affects the gut and central nervous system and is a human disease that is transmitted via a fecal-oral route. Salmonella and Campylobacter are associated with poultry and eggs primarily, whereas Vibrio is associated mainly with seafood.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with bloody diarrhea is admitted after laboratory results indicating anemia and abnormal kidney function. After testing, it is determined that the etiologic agent is an E. coli that is most likely to produce which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The verotoxin produced by E. coli is similar to Shiga toxin, causing bloody diarrhea.

choices.text: Proton pump inhibitor, antibiotic, and bismuth

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and upper abdominal pain. If the causative agent is a curved gram-negative rod with urease production, what treatment should be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The combination therapy of proton pump inhibitor, antibiotic, and bismuth is required to eradicate an infection with H. pylori.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital vomiting blood. He is diagnosed with a perforated peptic ulcer. The causative agent discovered by gastric biopsy is a spiral gram-negative bacillus. What other long-term complications could this organism cause if not treated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
 
Helicobacter pylori is the causative agent that can cause Type B gastritis, peptic ulcers, gastric adenocarcinoma, and gastric MALT B cell lymphomas.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby girl is suspected to have H. influenzae meningitis. She has not been immunized with the HIB vaccine. A rapid latex agglutination test is performed with the spinal fluid to make a definitive diagnosis. What chemical component in the spinal fluid are we detecting with this assay?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The latex agglutination test involves the use of latex beads coated with specific antibody that become agglutinated in the presence of homologous bacteria or antigen. This test is used to determine the presence of the capsular polysaccharide antigen of H. influenzae in serum or spinal fluid.

questions.text: A specimen of thick, bloody sputum from a hospitalized 80-year-old patient with diabetes mellitus and difficulty in breathing is sent for laboratory analyses. The tests yield heavy growth of a lactose-positive, nonmotile, gram-negative rod with a large capsule. Which of the following bacteria is most likely to be the cause of the pulmonary problems?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Whereas all of the above listed organisms are gram-negative rods, only K. pneumoniae fulfill all of the laboratory criteria listed in the question, such as the presence of a very large capsule, which gives a striking mucoid appearance to its colonies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency room with a severe productive cough producing thick bloody sputum resembling a “currant-jelly” like appearance. Culture using MacConkey agar reveals pink colonies, with large mucoid colonies on routine laboratory media. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient’s pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Patients with K. pneumoniae infections usually have predisposing conditions such as alcoholism, advanced age, chronic respiratory disease, and diabetes. The “currant-jelly” sputum distinguishes K. pneumoniae from the other organisms. Infections can lead to necrosis and abscess formation.

questions.text: A premature neonate suffers pneumonia and sepsis. Sputum culture on blood agar plate yields pinpointed β-hemolytic colonies. Which of the following is a simple test to determine whether the organism is S. agalactiae or L. monocytogenes (these two organisms are important neonatal pathogens)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Streptococcus agalactiae (group B streptococci) is the leading cause of neonatal sepsis and meningitis. All streptococci (including S. agalactiae) are catalase-negative, whereas staphylococci are catalasepositive. Listeria monocytogenes is also catalase-positive

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a chronic cough, bloody sputum, and marked weight loss is diagnosed as having tuberculosis. A “serpentine-like” colonial morphology is noted on Lowenstein-Jensen agar. This latter finding is caused by which of the following factors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Virulent strains of M. tuberculosis grow in a characteristic “serpentine” cord-like pattern, whereas avirulent strains do not. Virulence of the organism is correlated with cord factor (trehalose dimycolate).

questions.text: A 25-year-old man known to have AIDS experiences a gradual onset of malaise and anorexia, proceeding within a few weeks to photophobia, impaired consciousness, and oculofacial palsy. An acid-fast bacterium with trehalose-6, 6’-dimycolate is isolated. The identity of this organism is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis commonly has the trehalose dimycolate factor

questions.text: A 78-year-old patient with an episode of acute urinary retention was catheterized. Three days later, he developed fever and suprapubic pain. Culture of the urine revealed a thin film of bacterial growth over the entire blood agar plate, and the urease test was positive. Which of the following is the most likely organism to cause this infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Proteus species produce infections in humans only when the bacteria leave the intestinal tract. They are found in UTIs and produce bacteremia, pneumonia, and focal lesions in debilitated patients or those receiving intravenous infusions. Proteus mirabilis is a common cause of UTI. Proteus species produce urease, making urine alkaline and promoting stone formation. The rapid motility of these organisms is evidenced by “swarming,” a thin film of organisms over the entire agar plate.

questions.text: An aerobic, oxidase positive organism is isolated from the sputum of a 12-year-old cystic fibrosis patient with pneumonia and lung abscesses. On culture the organisms have a “fruity” odor and form greenish colonies. The etiologic agent of the respiratory tract infection is most likely to be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

All of the options are potential etiologic agents for pneumonias in humans. The laboratory descriptions of the organism best fits P. aeruginosa.

questions.text: A 4-year-old has fever and diarrhea. Blood culture grows a gramnegative rod. This is most likely to be which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Enterocolitis is the most common manifestation of Salmonella infection. Bacteremia is rare (2–4 percent) except in immunodeficient persons. Stool cultures may remain positive for Salmonella weeks after clinical recovery. Streptococci and Listeria stain grampositive, and Shigella organisms rarely, if ever, enter the blood stream from the intestines.
